title: 103_hr1448
content: The "Check Cashing Act of 1993" regulates check cashing services through licensing and regulation. The "Check Cashing Act of 1993" requires non-depository institutions to be licensed by the Commission to engage in issuing, redeeming, or cashing checks, travellers' checks, money orders, or transmitting money. The Commission may issue licenses based on business record, capital adequacy, and individual competence, experience, integrity, and financial ability. The Commission may deny a license based on criminal activity, fraud, breach of fiduciary duty, or suspension from participation in federally regulated activities. The Commission may revoke a license if the holder engages in prohibited activities, charges excessive fees, or violates regulations. Violators may face a civil penalty of up to $500,000. The Commission is required to issue implementing regulations within 9 months of the Act's enactment. The Commission must establish requirements for license applications and other activities under this section. The effective date for this section, except subsection (d), is 9 months after the Act's enactment. SEC. 3. LIMITATION ON FEE CHARGED FOR CHECK CASHING. A person cashing checks cannot charge a fee exceeding $0.50 or 0.85% of the amount. Civil penalty for violations can be up to $500,000. SEC. 4. PROHIBITION ON REFUSAL TO CASH GOVERNMENT CHECKS. A depository institution cannot refuse to cash a government check if presented by the payee with sufficient identification. Violators may face a civil penalty of up to $500,000. Enforcement falls under the Federal Deposit Insurance Act for national banks and Federal branches/agencies of foreign banks. The Federal Reserve oversees non-national banks, foreign bank branches, and commercial lending companies. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation regulates banks insured by them and state branches of foreign banks. The Office of Thrift Supervision enforces section 8 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The Office of Thrift Supervision oversees savings associations with insured deposits by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The Federal Credit Union Act is enforced by the Administrator of the National Credit Union Administration for Federal credit unions. The Farm Credit Act of 1971 is regulated by the Farm Credit Administration for Federal land banks and credit associations. SEC. 5. REQUIREMENT THAT CHECKS DRAWN BY FEDERAL AGENCIES BE MAILED ONLY TO CERTAIN ADDRESSES. Government checks issued by the United States or its agencies can only be mailed to the payee's residence, principal place of business, a post office box at a USPS facility, or the payee's account at an insured depository institution. This applies to checks mailed after 9 months from the enactment of this Act, with regulations to be issued by the Secretary of the Treasury within 2 months of enactment. SEC. 6. STUDY OF DEBIT CARD SYSTEM OF BENEFIT PAYMENTS AND BENEFIT CHECK DELIVERY. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the effects of using a debit card system for all Federal benefit payments and explore other ways to improve benefit check delivery methods. The Act defines key terms such as "Commission," "depository institution," "government check," and "insured depository institution." The Act defines key terms related to enforcement, including "sufficient identification" as a driver's license, state or federal ID card, or a US passport. Terms not defined in the Act refer to definitions in the Federal Deposit Insurance Act or the International Banking Act of 1978.
